Description: Archeological evidence suggests that humans have inhabited what is now San Diego County, including the border region, for at least 10,000 years. The Kumeyaay inhabit land that will encompass the cities of San Diego and Tijuana.

Over millennia, Native Americans in the region establish a rich and productive relationship with their natural environment. Natural resources cultivated by Native Americans support a regional population that numbers in the tens of thousands.
Native Americans in the region chart the sky as astronomers, master the botanical characteristics of local plants, and store water in wetlands.
Four ethnic groups living in the region include the Kumeyaay, Cupeño, Cahuilla, and Luiseño.
Native Americans harvest food from the sea, manage chaparral on coastal hills, maintain oak groves, and learn to cultivate resources in the deserts of what will become Imperial Valley.
Native Americans in the region become skilled horsemen and fur traders. They provide the labor force for the first Spanish-led communities.
The San Diego Mission is destroyed in an attack by Kumeyaay Native Americans, but it is rebuilt a year later.
The Catholic Asistencia is established at Pala.
The Catholic Asistencia is established at Santa Ysabel.
Mexico wins its independence from Spain, and San Diego becomes part of the Mexican territory of Alta California.
Independent Kumeyaay warriors begin to dominate most of inland San Diego County.
Source: San Diego Association of Governments/Southern California Tribal Chairmen’s Association. Proceedings for the 2010 San Diego Regional Tribal Summit.

Description: The Kumeyaay begin to launch repeated attacks on newly created ranchos.
San Diego is evacuated after a combined attack by Kumeyaay, Cocopa, and Quechan Native Americans.
The Mexican-American War begins. Under the terms of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo in 1848, the U.S. gains control of the San Diego area.
The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo results in Mexico ceding lands, including California, to the United States.
The city of San Diego is incorporated.
Local Native Americans provide domestic and day labor as San Diego begins to build city infrastructure.
There are 798 people in the San Diego region.
California becomes the 31st state of the United States of America.
The region's Native Americans work as tradesmen in coastal communities, and some become crewmen on whaling ships.
From 1850 to 1932, treaty lands, pueblo lands, and water sources are taken or diverted from local Native Americans to support a growing coastal population.
Native Americans become the first primary source of migratory crop pickers in California.
The Garra Revolt follows the severe mistreatment of Native Americans and the imposition of property taxes on tribes. The revolt is led by Cupeño leader Antonio Garra.
The San Diego County Board of Supervisors holds its first meeting.

Warner’s Pass (now known as San Pasqual Road) is declared a public road by the San Diego County Board of Supervisors. It serves as a main road between San Diego and the Colorado River until 1868, when stagecoaches begin using shorter routes to the south that lead through the pass at Jacumba.

James Birch establishes the “Jackass” mail route between San Diego and San Antonio. Passengers must traverse the Oriflamme Canyon and Colorado Desert on muleback. Stagecoach driver James E. Mason brings the first shipment of overland mail to town and decides to settle here.
There are 4,324 people in the San Diego region.
The iron ship Star of India, built on the Isle of Man in 1863, is towed to San Diego. It remains in disrepair over the next 30 years.
The Kimball brothers buy 26,400 acres of Rancho de la Nacion and lay out National City.
Ephraim Morse presents a resolution to the Board of Trustees of San Diego that land be set aside for a city park. Morse, Thomas Bush, and Alonzo Horton select the land now known as Balboa Park.
Alonzo Horton completes a wharf at the end of 5th Avenue at a cost of about $45,000. On March 24, he sells $5,500 worth of commercial and residential lots in one day. The new town begins to boom.
Albert Seeley purchases the run-down Bandini Adobe in Old Town and spends the next six months renovating the old home to create the Cosmopolitan Hotel. He also builds the Seeley Stables next door.

Horton Hall opens around Christmas 1869. This two-story brick building on the southeast corner of 6th Avenue and F Street has shops downstairs and a meeting hall with 400 seats upstairs. The hall becomes downtown’s first public theater.
There are 4,951 people in the San Diego region.
The Bank of San Diego becomes the first bank in San Diego. It is followed by the Commercial Bank of San Diego in 1872. The two banks merge to become the Consolidated Bank of San Diego in 1879.
San Diego's first major hotel is built.
San Diego becomes the first city west of the Mississippi to set aside land for an urban park. This 1,440-acre tract becomes the site for City Park, now known as Balboa Park.
Thomas Scott of Pennsylvania Railroad sparks a brief boom in railroad development when he begins construction of the Texas & Pacific Railroad from San Diego toward the east.

After a delegation of Kumeyaay and Luiseño Native Americans led by Luiseño Olegario Calac meet with President Ulysses S. Grant, he signs an executive order creating the Santa Ysabel, Pala, Sycuan, La Jolla, Rincon, and Capitan Grande reservations.
Lieutenant Reade of the U.S. Weather Bureau gives the first public demonstration of the telephone in San Diego County.
From 1880 to 1933, local Native Americans provide the labor that builds the region's first highways, telegraph lines, and railroad tracks traversing the region's eastern mountains and deserts.
From 1880 to 1933, railroad and real estate speculators, as well as city boosters, create a glamorized portrayal of California history and its missions.
There are 8,618 people in the San Diego region.
Frank Kimball of National City establishes the San Diego County Fair.
California Southern begins construction of San Diego’s first outside rail connection. The line extends from National City to the town of Colton.
Carlsbad mineral water is discovered.
The San Diego Telephone Company begins operation.
John Montgomery conducts the world’s first controlled flight in a heavier-than-air craft. He flies 600 feet in a glider at Otay Mesa. Montgomery is later killed in a glider crash in 1911.

From 1885 to 1890, several independent railroad lines are constructed: the Central California; the National City & Otay; the San Diego, the Old Town & Pacific Beach; the Coronado; and the San Diego, Cuyamaca and Eastern. In addition, Santa Fe builds a new link from Oceanside to Orange County — the “Surf Line.” San Diego’s first horsedrawn trolleys begin service on the city’s streets.
The nation's transcontinental railroad reaches San Diego. The first train of the California Southern departs from San Diego on November 15, and on November 21 the first train arrives from the east.
Construction of Hotel del Coronado begins in 1886.
San Diego Street Car Company begins service.
The first electric street lights are installed in San Diego.
National City is incorporated.
The first electric motor makes a test run on new tracks up Broadway to Kettner Boulevard and on to Old Town.
The federal Dawes Act, sometimes referred to as the Dawes Severalty Act or the General Allotment Act, becomes law. It allows the federal government to break up tribal lands.
The city of Escondido is incorporated.
The city of Oceanside is incorporated.
San Diego’s 1880s real estate boom ends. By the end of the decade, the city's population has dropped from 40,000 to 16,000.

Sweetwater Dam, a major engineering feat and San Diego County’s first major dam supplying water to National City and Chula Vista, is completed by the Kimball Brothers Water Company. The dam is 396 feet long and 12 feet wide at the top, and 75 feet in length and 46 feet wide at the base. Original plans for building the dam 60 feet in height were changed to 98 feet, increasing capacity of the reservoir fivefold.
The city of Coronado is incorporated.
There are 34,987 people in the San Diego region.
Fisher Opera House opens on Fourth Avenue between B and C streets. It is an opulent but practical house that seats 1,400 people and is regarded as the best theater on the West Coast.
Wall Street panic leads to The Great Depression.

Bad times encourage Alonzo Horton to sell his half-block Horton Plaza park to the city for $10,000, but he stipulates that it must remain a park forever. Under the agreement, the city agrees to pay Horton $100 a month with no interest and no down payment. In the event of Horton’s death, the city would acquire the property outright. The city fathers underestimate Horton’s endurance. In April 1903, 89-year-old Horton cashes the final payment for a total of $16,000. Today Horton’s park fronts Horton Plaza and has been renamed Horton Plaza Park.
San Diego State University opens.

The U.S. Army establishes Fort Rosecrans, named after General William Rosecrans, an 1842 graduate of the U.S. Military Academy. It remains an Army base until it is transferred to the Navy in 1959 for the purpose of building a submarine base at Ballast Point.
There are 35,090 people in the San Diego region.
By decision of the U.S. Supreme Court, Indian inhabitants of Cupa, San Felipe, and nearby villages around Warner Springs are evicted and removed to lands near the Pala Reservation.
The Cupeño people are forcibly removed from their ancestral village of Kupa (Warner Springs) and relocated to the Pala Reservation.

San Diego County Hospital opens at the north end of Front Street, on a mesa overlooking Mission Valley. The total cost is about $60,000. The 90 patients residing in the previous county medical institution, the County Poor Farm in Mission Valley, are transferred up the hill on May 15th.
Development of Presidio Park begins. George Marston and other investors begin buying Presidio property to preserve as a park.
San Diego leaders persuade President Theodore Roosevelt's "Great White Fleet" to anchor off the coast of Coronado and consider making San Diego Bay a U.S. Navy base of operations.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: There are 61,665 people in the San Diego region.
The city of Chula Vista is incorporated.
Glenn Hammond Curtiss conducts the world’s first successful seaplane flight from waters off Spanish Bight, which stretches a mile between North Island and Coronado (now filled in).
The first Miramar Air show is held.
The city of La Mesa is incorporated.
The city of El Cajon is incorporated.
Spruce Street’s suspension bridge, between Front and Brant streets, is built to give residents access to streetcars running along 4th Avenue.
The U.S. Navy establishes a base on North Island, with three airplanes and three fliers. On Thanksgiving Day, the Army Signal Corps establishes Rockwell Field with an aviation school on North Island.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: Spreckels Theatre opens with 1,915 seats (the year of the coming Exposition). It is the first modern commercial playhouse west of the Mississippi.
Broadway Pier is constructed with a $1.7 million bond issued by the city.
Construction of the Santa Fe Depot train station begins on June 15, replacing the earlier Grand Union Depot.

Cabrillo Bridge opens on April 12, 1914. The first car to drive across the bridge carries Franklin D. Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy; G. Aubrey Davidson; and Mayor Charles F. O’Neall as passengers.
The Santa Fe Depot train station in downtown San Diego opens.
San Diego hosts the Panama-California Exposition, raising its visibility nationwide.
Dr. Harry Wegeforth brings the San Diego Zoo into being when animals imported for the 1915 Panama-California Exposition are quarantined and not allowed to leave.
Army Camp Kearny (later MCAS Miramar) and Marine Corps Camp Mathews (later UC San Diego) are established.
The U.S. Navy opens the most powerful radio station in the Western Hemisphere at Chollas Heights.

World War I prompts a military buildup in San Diego. Camp Kearny is established, named in honor of Gen. Stephen Kearny who led the Army of the West to San Diego in 1846. It costs $4.5 million to build and is closed in 1920.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: A U.S. Marine Base and Naval Hospital are approved. The federal government purchases North Island, and its Rockwell Field is shared by the Army and Navy until 1939.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: The San Diego & Arizona Railroad is finally completed. John D. Spreckels drives the final golden spike as 1,000 spectators watch. After 13 years of labor and $17 million of investment, San Diego achieves a direct link to the east.
Commander Navy Southwest is established (formerly known as Naval Base San Diego / Eleventh Naval District).
San Diego’s Pacific Marine Construction company launches two concrete ships, the Cuyamaca and the San Pasqual. Begun during WWI but completed after the war ended, both ships serve as oil tankers.
Many Native Americans in California join together to challenge federal powers through the Mission Indian Federation.
There are 112,248 people in the San Diego region.
Naval Training Center San Diego (Marine Corps Recruit Depot) is established.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: The first motor bus begins service from Chula Vista to National City.
U.S. Navy Destroyer Base (Naval Base San Diego) is established.
Naval Hospital Balboa Park is commissioned on August 22, with an initial capacity of 250 beds.
The first U.S. aircraft carrier (the U.S.S. Langley) begins to operate out of North Island.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: Ellen Browning Scripps donates $250,000 to establish the 44-bed Scripps Hospital in La Jolla.
The U.S. Naval Hospital is established.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: The Mission Beach Amusement Center (now Belmont Park) opens.

Charles Lindbergh departs from Rockwell field at North Island, Coronado, in the Spirit of St. Louis. The aircraft is a custom-built M-1 monoplane built in San Diego by Ryan Airlines. Lindbergh completes his historic solo nonstop flight from New York to Paris May 20-21.
The El Cortez Hotel opens as San Diego’s “finest” furnished apartment-hotel.
The Fine Arts Gallery in Balboa Park, designed by William Templeton Johnson and funded by Appleton Bridges, is dedicated and opens to the public. Today it is known as the San Diego Museum of Art.
Native Americans in California challenge past U.S. actions, and they obtain a partial settlement of some claims.
San Diego Municipal Airport – Lindbergh Field is dedicated.
At San Diego Municipal Airport - Lindbergh Field, the San Diego-Los Angeles airmail route debuts on June 1. At 5 p.m. sharp, the first airmail plane departs the only building at the airport.
There are 209,659 people in the San Diego region.

The people of the Capitan Grande reservation, established in 1875, are moved to two different reservations in 1932 after the City of San Diego acquires 7,000 acres of land for the El Capitan Reservoir.
Reuben H. Fleet moves Consolidated Aircraft (which becomes Convair) from Buffalo, New York to San Diego. Fleet had organized the first U.S. Air Mail Service in 1918.
The eleventh district of the California Division of Highways is established.
The first hospital in Escondido opens as "Escondido Community Hospital."
The Natural History Museum opens in Balboa Park.

The federal Wheeler-Howard Act, also known as the Indian Reorganization Act (IRA), is aimed at decreasing federal control of Native American affairs and increasing self-government and responsibility. The Act offers federal subsidies to tribes that adopt constitutions like that of the United States and replace their governments with city council-style governments.

Consolidated Aircraft opens its first plant along Pacific Highway to build 50 P-30 pursuit planes for the U.S. Army. The first test flight of the PBY-1 amphibious aircraft takes place at San Diego Bay a year later in 1936. Consair employment rises from 900 to 3,700.
The Old Globe Theatre opens in Balboa Park.
The Del Mar Turf Club (Del Mar Race Track) opens.

Richard Archbold conducts the first transcontinental flight from San Diego to New York City in a seaplane built by Consair. The following year, the Archbold expedition, with pilots Steve Barinka and Russell Rogers, sets off from San Diego on a global survey of potential oceanic and continental air routes. The Archbold expedition arrives back in San Diego on July 6, 1939 as the first around-the-world seaplane flight at the equator.
The U.S. Coast Guard Air Station is established.
The San Diego Civic Center opens.
A National War Emergency is declared.
Naval Air Station, Miramar develops on the site of Camp Kearny.
Goodrich Corp. Aerostructures Systems is established in San Diego.
Marine Base Camp Elliott is established.
There are 289,348 people in the San Diego region.
Native Americans nationwide volunteer in large numbers to fight in World War II.
Source: San Diego Association of Governments/Southern California Tribal Chairmen’s Association. Proceedings for the 2014 San Diego Regional Tribal Summit.

Description: San Diego Naval Air Station begins training pilots for the U.S. Air Force (31,400 pilots will be trained here during World War II).
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: Construction begins on the Linda Vista defense housing project. It is the biggest construction job to date in San Diego history; McNeil and Zoss contract to build 3,000 units in 300 days for $9,070,000.

The U.S. Army Air Corps takes over Lindbergh Field in 1942, and Army engineers improve the airport's existing runways to accommodate heavy bombers churned out by San Diego's aircraft manufacturers during World War II.
The U.S. Navy acquires Rancho Santa Margarita, 126,000 acres north of Oceanside, for the Camp Pendleton Marine Base.
The U.S. Navy begins emergency construction of an aqueduct to bring Colorado River water to San Diego.
The Navy Electronics Laboratory is established.
World War II ends. San Diego soon experiences a recession.
By the end of WWII, the Naval Hospital grows to 241 buildings with 10,499 beds.
San Diego voters approve a $2 million bond to begin developing Mission Bay.
Submarine Group San Diego (Naval Base Point Loma) is established.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: Palomar Observatory opens in June. Construction of the 200-inch mirror for the observatory's Hale Telescope had begun in 1934. The Hale Telescope at Palomar Observatory is the largest optical telescope in the world from 1949 until 1975.
Construction begins on University of San Diego's first college.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: Pacific Southwest Airlines (PSA) establishes its headquarters in San Diego and begins service at Lindbergh Field.
There are 556,808 people in the San Diego region.
Palomar Memorial Hospital opens with a capacity of 37 beds.
Cubic, Inc. is established in San Diego.
The city of Carlsbad is incorporated.
Miramar Naval Air Station is established.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: The San Diego Open (now the Farmers Insurance Open) holds its first annual golf tournament.
San Diego's City Charter amendment gives the City Council the authority to build or approve the construction of any roads within city parks.
WD-40 is invented in a small lab in San Diego.
The Naval Hospital treats about 90,000 patients during the Korean conflict.
The San Diego City Council gives the University of California “city-owned land for students who are desirous of entering into the professional field of engineering.”
General Atomics is founded in San Diego.
Grossmont Hospital opens.
San Diego City Council gives 300 acres of land on the Torrey Pines mesa to the new research firm, General Atomics.
The city of Imperial Beach is incorporated.
The first test launch of the U.S. Air Force Atlas A missile, built by Convair in San Diego, is conducted from Cape Canaveral in Florida. Fort Rosecrans is transferred to the U.S. Navy.
Donald N. Sharp Memorial Community Hospital performs San Diego's first cardiac catheterization, a procedure that enables cardiologists to see inside the heart and major arteries.
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs San Diego's first open-heart surgery.
The San Diego City Council approves a zone change to allow May Department Stores Company to build a shopping center in Mission Valley. The Mall, the first in the county, is completed in 1961.
Interstate 8 opens in February. The highway follows ancient Indian trails through Mission Valley.
The city of San Diego gives the University of California additional real estate for the new UC San Diego campus.
The city of Del Mar is incorporated.
General Dynamics is established in San Diego.
The city of San Diego gives the University of California additional real estate for the new UC San Diego campus.
In a special referendum, the citizens of San Diego overwhelmingly approve the gift of 27 acres of pueblo lands on the Torrey Pines mesa to the new Salk Institute for Biological Studies.
In September, United Airlines becomes the first airline to offer entirely jet service at Lindbergh Field.
San Diego State College becomes a member of the California State University system.

On November 18, the University of California, San Diego is officially established and students enroll. The campus is realized through state appropriations, a donation from General Dynamics, and a gift from the City of San Diego of 63 acres of pueblo land northeast of Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: San Diego State College (later SDSU) establishes the KPBS-FM educational radio station.
There are 1,033,011 people in the San Diego region.
California voters approve a proposition to deliver water from Northern California to as far south as San Diego.
Sharp Memorial Hospital installs the first electronic pacemaker west of St. Louis.
The Mission Valley Shopping Center opens.
The Grossmont Shopping Center opens.
The American Football League's Chargers begin their first season at Balboa Stadium.
Mission Valley Shopping Center opens.
San Diego Unified Port District is established.
The first major long-term rehabilitation center specializing in care for patients with spinal cord, stroke, and brain injuries opens at Sharp Memorial Hospital.
The city of San Marcos is incorporated.
The city of Vista is incorporated.
The Tenth Avenue Marine Terminal Bulkloading Facility is completed by the San Diego Unified Port District.
John F. Kennedy gives a commencement speech at San Diego State College (later SDSU).
Construction of Hillcrest Hospital is completed in July at a cost of $11.5 million.

The Bracero program (the official temporary worker arrangement started in 1942) ends, prompting a flow of migrant workers back to Mexico. The Mexican government establishes an industrialization program to create jobs for these workers. Maquiladoras, or “assembly plants,” are built in border towns to employ Mexican laborers who will assemble goods for the U.S. market. The maquiladora industry increases interdependance between the countries.
UC San Diego opens a 1,000-acre La Jolla campus.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The new 240-bed Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla opens on Genesee Avenue.
Seaworld opens.
Maxwell Technologies, Inc. is established in San Diego.
Mexico authorizes maquiladora factories, Mexican assembly or manufacturing operations that can be wholly or partially owned and managed by non-Mexican companies.
Under a state authorized joint powers agreement, local governments create the Comprehensive Planning Organization (CPO) as a long-range planning department within the San Diego County government.
UC San Diego begins operating “University Hospital” as its primary clinical teaching facility. Second College is renamed after conservationist and author, John Muir.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The Sports Arena in San Diego's Midway area is completed by Bob Breitbard.
UC San Diego Health announces plans to open the region’s first kidney transplant unit.

The $27 million San Diego Stadium opens in Mission Valley as the home stadium for the San Diego Chargers and the San Diego State University Aztecs football team. In 1969 it is expanded to also become the home stadium for the San Diego Padres baseball team.
The city's "Committee of 100" leads a successful bond drive to raise money for the first historic reconstruction of Balboa Park. Casa del Prado is completed in 1971.
Story: CREATING A VACATION WONDERLAND ; PHILANTHROPY AND CIVIC INVESTMENT

Description: Cargo handling begins at the National City Marine Terminal.
A pioneering family planning clinic is opened at UC San Diego, offering contraception information and all types of birth control options.
UC San Diego Health performs its first organ transplant, a kidney transplant, on a 32-year-old former aircraft worker with a kidney donated by his older brother.
The minor-league San Diego Padres become a major league baseball team.

The Indian Civil Rights Act of 1968 becomes law. Like the U.S. Constitution's Bill of Rights, it says that Indian tribal governments cannot pass or enforce laws that violate certain individual rights.
The San Diego-Coronado Bay Bridge opens.
The San Diego-Coronado Bridge opens.
Fashion Valley Mall opens.

California Governor Ronald Reagan designates the CPO as the Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) to promote areawide coordination on a variety of efforts. MPOs around the state become an important resource of information and technical guidance for local governments.
The San Diego City Council dedicates 6,000 acres for the new La Jolla Underwater Park.
San Diego's Mexican-American community campaigns for the creation of Chicano Park beneath San Diego-Coronado Bay Bridge.
There are 1,357,854 people in the San Diego region.
The world famous Comic-Con holds its first convention in San Diego.
The first cruise ship to offer ocean voyages out of the Port of San Diego begins making trips to Mexico.
A representative from Mexico becomes a SANDAG Advisory Board Member. Former City of San Diego Councilmember Jim Bates led this initiative.
The State of California further designates the CPO as the Regional Transportation Planning Agency, the Airport Land Use Commission, and an areawide clearinghouse for federal/state grant reviews.
Kyocera is established in San Diego.
Bazaar del Mundo opens shops in Old Town that feature specialty gifts and other items from Latin America.
Local governments in San Diego County establish the CPO as an independent Joint Powers Agency.

San Diego is chosen as the site of the Republican National Convention, but in a last-minute change the Republican Party announces it will move the convention to Miami Beach. The loss of the convention prompts San Diego Mayor Pete Wilson to declare San Diego “America’s Finest City.”

The Southern California Tribal Chairmen's Association (SCTCA) is established. The SCTCA is a nonprofit organization composed of 20 federally recognized Native American tribes in Southern California. Its goals are to serve the health, welfare, and cultural and economic needs of tribal members.
Sharp Memorial Hospital features San Diego's first fully computerized laboratory reporting system.

Sharp Memorial Hospital introduces San Diego's first patient representative program with a full-time staff member. The representative acts as an advocate for patients in meeting their needs and concerns during hospitalization.
The Veterans Administration opens a $48 million hospital.
A shopping center opens in El Cajon; it is later named Parkway Plaza.
The Reuben H. Fleet Space Theater opens to the public in Balboa Park.
UC San Diego neurologists successfully treat refractory epilepsy patients with a special brain surgery that removes small sections of the brain where seizures occur.
Sharp HealthCare introduces the first driver-education program for disabled individuals in San Diego.
San Diego County's CPO develops and adopts the region's first Regional Transportation Plan.
San Diego Mayor Pete Wilson launches plans for a dramatic redevelopment of downtown San Diego, creating the Centre City Development Corporation.
The Jamul Indian Village finally receives federal trust status. Other landless California tribes, including the San Luis Rey Band of Mission Indians, continue to seek federal recognition.

The Indian Self Determination and Education Assistance Act of 1975 (ISDEAA) becomes law. It authorizes the federal Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare, and other government agencies to enter into contracts with and make grants to federally recognized Native American tribes.
Sharp HealthCare debuts San Diego's first hospital-based alcohol and drug treatment program.
San Diego debuts the first total body Computerized Tomography (CT) scanner to provide a three-dimensional detailed image of internal organs.
UC San Diego Health opens a Regional Trauma Center.
The city of Lemon Grove is incorporated.
San Diego Transit carries more than 30 million passengers on 44 routes with a fleet of 350 buses and a flat-rate fare of 35 cents.
The UC San Diego Outpatient Center in Hillcrest is completed.
San Diego Hospice is founded.
Pomerado Hospital opens as the District’s second hospital, which today is a 107-bed acute-care facility.
University Towne Centre shopping mall opens near UC San Diego.

The Local Technical Assistance (LTA) program is established for member governments. The CPO helps establish the Automated Regional Justice Information System (ARJIS). The CPO is jointly designated, with the San Diego County government, to implement the federal and state clean air acts.

San Diego's first biotechnology company, Hybritech, is co-founded by UC San Diego assistant professor Ivor Royston and his research assistant Howard Birndorf. Since then faculty, staff, and alumni have created more than 640 companies, including many local biotech firms.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) becomes law. Its purpose is to "protect the best interest of Indian Children and to promote the stability and security of Indian tribes and families by the establishment of minimum Federal standards for the removal of Indian children and placement of such children in homes which will reflect the unique values of Indian culture. ..."
MTDB's Board Member Maureen O'Connor negotiates the purchase of SD&AE Railway For $18.1 million. Annual ridership in this decade improves from 18 million to 35 million.
The Life Flight helicopter-ambulance program is inaugurated.
The city of Poway is incorporated.
The city of Santee is incorporated.
The CPO re-names itself the San Diego Association of Governments, or SANDAG.
The San Diego Trolley, the first line in the city’s new light-rail transit system, is dedicated.

SANDAG and the U.S. Department of Defense (U.S. DOD) entered into a Memorandum of
Agreement (MOA) for the purpose of assuring a cooperative and mutually beneficial working
relationship.
There are 1,861,846 people in the San Diego region.
Gaming grows in importance for some of the region's Native Americans.
The San Diego Trolley begins service to the international border with Mexico. The inaugural run takes place on 15.9 "South Line" between the international norder and Downtown San Diego.
The San Diego Trolley begins service to the international border. The inaugural run takes place between the border and Downtown San Diego.
Plaza Bonita shopping center opens in National City.
Many employers begin to offer employees preferred provider organizations (PPOs) and HMO plans other than Kaiser.
The Otay Mesa Land Port of Entry (POE) opens to traffic, providing travelers with additional crossborder capacity.
The Otay Mesa-Mesa de Otay Land Port of Entry (POE) opens.
Sharp HealthCare creates the first hospital-based program designed for the young children of alcoholics and other chemically dependent parents at Sharp Vista Pacifica.
The National Institute on Aging designates UC San Diego as one of the nation's first five Alzheimer’s disease research centers.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The Horton Plaza shopping center opens.
The East Line for the San Diego Trolley is completed.
The Otay Mesa-Mesa de Otay POE opens to bidirectional passenger and northbound commercial traffic. Southbound commercial processing continues in San Ysidro at Virginia Avenue.
Axelgaard Manufacturing Co. Ltd is established in San Diego.
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs the first implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD).
Horton Plaza shopping center opens as a $140 million cornerstone of downtown redevelopment.
The city of Encinitas is incorporated.
The city of Solana Beach is incorporated.
The San Diego Supercomputer Center opens at UC San Diego, providing the national research community with access to the highest-performance computers available.​
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The San Diego Supercomputer Center opens at UC San Diego.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: ViaSat, Inc. is established in San Diego.
North County Fair shopping center opens in Escondido.

The U.S. Supreme Court, in the case California v. Cabazon Band of Mission Indians, rule that Indian Nations have the right to establish gaming standards for any activities that are legal in the State.
UC San Diego alumnus Susumu Tonegawa wins the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of the genetic mechanism that produces antibody diversity.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: Life Technologies Corporation is established in San Diego.
Voters approve the regional TransNet ordinance to help fund transportation improvements around the region.
The Federal Indian Gaming Regulatory Act (IGRA) passes after a long legal battle that reaches the U.S. Supreme Court. The Act provides framing for the national regulation of Native American gaming.
San Diego hosts its first Super Bowl.
Del Mar Highland Town Center opens.
SANDAG helps establish the San Dieguito River Valley Park Joint Powers Authority.
Former San Diego Mayor Pete Wilson is elected Governor of California. He is the state’s first governor from San Diego.
The Bayside Line for the San Diego Trolley is completed.
The National City Marine Terminal receives its first imports of vehicles.
The Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act becomes law. It provides for the protection and repatriation of Native American remains and cultural items.
California State University, San Marcos (CSUSM) opens.
There are 2,498,016 people in the San Diego region.
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs its first kidney transplant on July 19, 1990.
Scripps Green Hospital starts San Diego’s first successful liver transplant program.
Most Native American tribes in the nation have developed or have agreements to establish gaming facilities as a means of economic development.
The North Line for the San Diego Trolley is completed.

The State of California designates SANDAG as the San Diego-Coronado Bridge Toll Authority. SANDAG also helps form a five-county rail coalition, and purchases rail right-of-way from the Santa Fe Railway for the COASTER, as well as SPRINTER rail commuter service between Oceanside and Escondido.
Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego opens the Stephen Birch Aquarium and Museum on September 16, 1992.
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs its first heart-lung transplant surgery.
The California Public Employees Retirement System (CalPERS) takes an assertive bargaining stance with health plans on behalf of its one million state and local government enrollees.
Susan Golding is elected mayor of the City of San Diego.
The Shoreline Preservation Strategy for the San Diego region is published.
General Atomics Aeronautical Systems, Inc. is established in San Diego.

The North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is enacted. Side agreements result in the creation of the North American Development Bank (NADB) and the Border Environmental Cooperation Commission (BECC), spurring high levels of border related investment.

The North America Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is enacted. Side agreements result in the creation of the North American Development Bank (NADB) and the Border Environmental Cooperation Commission (BECC), spurring high levels of border-related investment.

Operation Gatekeeper is enacted, leading to the construction of fence refortifications along the border and increasing the budget for the U.S. Border Patrol. Over the next few years, the number of officers and budget for the U.S. Border Patrol doubles.

The San Diego County Water Authority joins SANDAG as an advisory member. SANDAG plays a major role in bringing together, and most importantly, holding together, all participants in the San Diego County Investment Fund.
COASTER rail service begins.

The Virginia Avenue border crossing in San Ysidro (located at the site of today's PedWest facility) closes for commercial operations. These operations are consolidated at the Otay Mesa-Mesa de Otay POE.

The Nearshore Habitat Inventory is developed. A regional Geographic Information System of the nearshore coastal environment, the inventory serves as a clearinghouse for data and projects affecting nearshore resources.
General Dynamics closes its Convair division in San Diego.
HMOs account for about half of 2.1 million insured enrollees, including two-thirds of employment-based health insurance enrollees, 43% of Medicare enrollees, and about 17% of Medi-Cal enrollees.
The City of San Diego hosts the Republican National Convention. It is the first time the city has hosted a national political convention.
SANDAG launches the I-15 FasTrak Program to improve traffic flow on the highway, and to expand bus and rideshare services along the corridor.
SANDAG creates the Committee on Binational Regional Opportunities (COBRO) to help coordinate efforts related to increasingly dynamic border issues.
The Secure Electronic Network for Travelers Rapid Inspection (SENTRI) lane opens at Otay Mesa POE (1 lane). It is the first of its kind to be implemented in the U.S.
The Regional Beach Monitoring Program is established.
The San Diego Regional Clean Cities Coalition is designated.
UC San Diego Health surgeons successfully separate conjoined twins, born attached at the chest and abdomen. The separated twins are discharged nine days later.

SANDAG and COBRO begin hosting Annual Binational Events to bring together stakeholders from both sides of the border. Their goal is to find solutions and identify opportunities related to a wide range of topics. These include water and energy supplies, crossborder climate change, border wait times, and homeland security.
In South County, the Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP) is approved.
Coors Amphitheatre opens in Chula Vista.
The Port of San Diego expands Lindbergh Field by adding Terminal 2.
Voters approve propositions to expand the San Diego Convention Center, build a new ballpark for the San Diego Padres downtown, and issue $1.5 billion in city school bonds.
Story: CREATING A VACATION WONDERLAND ; PHILANTHROPY AND CIVIC INVESTMENT

Description: The Mission Valley Line for the San Diego Trolley is completed.
The U.S. Navy embarks on a new era of shore management.
Scripps Center for Women’s Health, which includes 12 state-of-the-art birthing suites, opens at Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla.
The newly renamed Qualcomm Stadium in Mission Valley hosts the Super Bowl.
The Rock n’ Roll Marathon holds its inaugural event.
Mexico surpasses Japan to become California’s top export trade market. In 1999 Mexico is second in total trade with the U.S., but in 2006 it will be surpassed by China.
Scripps Health, Scripps Clinic, and The Scripps Research Institute join forces to create the Scripps Cancer Center integrating basic research, clinical research, cancer care, and community outreach.
Legoland California opens in Carlsbad.
MTDB and NCTD join SANDAG as advisory members, and SANDAG joins the Joint Committee on Regional Transit.
The Disaster Mitigation Act of 2000 becomes law. It requires state, local, and Indian tribal governments to coordinate planning and implementation efforts to reduce the impact of hazard events.

A connecting roadway to the Otay Mesa-Mesa de Otay POE (then Otay Mesa Road) is designated as an expressway and widened to six lanes in 2000. Before this expansion, the roadway experienced 50% more traffic than it was designed to handle. The San Diego Union-Tribune considered it "California's busiest trade route with Mexico."
A SENTRI lane is implemented at the San Ysidro POE.
SANDAG adopts the $29 billion, 20-year Regional Transportation Plan to reduce traffic congestion and limit urban sprawl.
There are 2,813,833 people in the San Diego region.

Multiple Species Conservation Plans (MSCPs) and Multiple Habitat Conservation Plans (MHCPs) are developed for many cities in the region. Tribal nations express frustration over the lack of inclusion of tribal boundaries in these plans.
Source: San Diego Regional Water Authority. Chapter 4 – Tribal Nations in San Diego County, San Diego Integrated Regional Water Management Plan.

Description: The C-TPAT secure-cargo shipping program is launched.
San Diego County establishes a Tribal Liaison Program.

SANDAG establishes the Borders Policy Committee, which is later reaffirmed in 2003 by California Senate Bill 1703. The committee includes Imperial County as a regular member, and representatives from neighboring Orange and Riverside Counties as well as Mexico. Tribal Governments, through the Southern California Tribal Chairmen’s Association, become Advisory Members of the committee, and later of the SANDAG Board of Directors and other PACs.
The terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001 change the dynamics of border crossings around the country. Protective measures at the nation's borders begin scaling up.
The C-TPAT secure-cargo shipping program launches.
The Regional Beach Sand Project replenishes sand at the county's beaches.
Las Americas Premium Outlets opens in San Ysidro.
The Regional Beach Monitoring Program Annual Report and Appendixes are initiated.
California's Native American Historic Resource Protection Act is passed to provide avenues for the state's Native American tribes to protect their historical cultural lands.
SANDAG drafts a $42 billion, 30-year Regional Transportation Plan that aims to make public transit competitive with solo driving during rush hours.
SANDAG holds a policy development board meeting with tribal nations.
Caltrans District 11 establishes a Native American Tribal Liaison Program.

Under the Homeland Security Act (2002), the federal government establishes the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). Security, compliance, and facilitation of international travel and trade is consolidated under Customs and Border Protection (U.S. CBP).

DHS implements heightened security measures, shifting from mostly randomized screenings of cars and people to comprehensive checks for nearly all crossers. Other screenings include the collection of fingerprints and biometric data (i.e., USVISIT program). The level of comprehensive checks decrease over time as CBP begins to experience capacity/resource issues.
The State of the Coast Report is published under the Regional Beach Monitoring Program.
Sharp Memorial Hospital performs the first heart-kidney transplant in San Diego.
Scripps opens Mercy Gardens to house AIDS/HIV patients on the campus of Scripps Mercy Hospital.

With the passage of state law (Senate Bill 1703), SANDAG becomes a consolidated regional agency on January 1. Over the next 13 months, transit planning, programming, project development, and construction will be consolidated into the regional agency. Also during this time, Imperial County joins SANDAG as an advisory board member.
Imperial County joins SANDAG as an advisory board member.

The County of San Diego conducts a Traffic Impact Assessment related to tribal developments. The report identifies improvement opportunities on State Routes 76, 67, and 94, as they are heavily trafficked roads for people heading to gaming facilities.
Caltrans and SANDAG create the first regional map that includes tribal nations.
In North County, the Multiple Habitat Conservation Program (MHCP) is initiated.
Series 10: 2030 Regional Growth Forecast - Historical Projection is adopted.
Super Bowl XXXVII is held at Qualcomm Stadium.
The Automated Regional Justice System (ARJIS) is consolidated into SANDAG.
The U.S.S. Midway aircraft carrier opens as a museum to the public.
In November, voters approve to extend the TransNet ordinance to 2048, to continue helping to fund transportation improvements around the region.
Petco Park, the new home stadium for the San Diego Padres, opens.

BNSF is the major freight carrier in the county, and its main rail line extends from the border with Orange County down the coast to National City. The port of San Diego is the county's major freight supplier. In 2004 BNSF moved 2.8 million tons of freight, an increase of 23.3% over 2003. BNSF also has a branch line between Escondido and Oceanside.
Congress passes the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act, which authorizes increased spending to add 10,000 new agents to the U.S. Border Patrol.
The Smart Growth Concept Map is revealed.
The TransNet Environmental Mitigation Program is approved.
Carlsbad Premium Outlets opens a name-brand and designer outlet shopping center.

California Senate Bill 18 passes in 2004 to protect Native American prehistoric, archaeological, cultural, spiritual, and ceremonial places. It requires local governments to consult with tribes at the earliest possible point in the land use planning process so that these places can be identified and considered for preservation.
The Independent Taxpayer Oversight Committee (ITOC) is formed in accordance with the TransNet ordinance to monitor program operations.

To better understand the transportation needs of Native American tribes in the region, Caltrans District 11 and SANDAG in 2005 designed, developed, and implemented a joint Tribal Transportation Needs Survey.
The Environmental Mitigation Program Working Group is established.

The funding formula for the Indian Reservation Roads (IRR) program -- part of the federal Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act: A Legacy for Users (SAFETEA-LU) -- is revised to allow tribes to include off-reservation transportation facilities that are critical to their transportation system.

In 2006, approximately $29.8 billion in trade was handled by the Otay Mesa and Tecate Ports of Entry in
San Diego County.
The San Diego Regional Tribal Summit is hosted by the Pala Band of Mission Indians.

The Interagency Technical Working Group on Tribal Transportation is formed to facilitate exchanges between tribal nations and public agencies. Fourteen of the 17 tribes in the region are members of the group.
Source: California  v Cabazon Band of Mission Indians, 480 U.S. 202 (1987)

Description: The Intertribal Court of Southern California begins operations.
SANDAG completes the study, "Economic Impacts of Wait Times at the San Diego-Baja California Border." It is the first to quantify the economic impacts of delays experienced at the border.
The Sand Compatibility and Opportunistic Use Program is prepared.
Series 11: 2030 Regional Growth Forecast Update - Historical Projection is adopted.
Otay Ranch Shopping Center opens.
The Southern California Tribal Chairman's Association joins SANDAG as an advisory member.
SANDAG is awarded $432 million in state infrastructure bond dollars for transportation improvements.
SANDAG and the City of Tijuana approve the Otay Mesa-Mesa de Otay Binational Corridor Strategic Plan.
The Poomacha Fire burns 99% of the La Jolla reservation, devastating the local community of Luiseño Native Americans.
Source: Banegas, Ethan L., "The Socioeconomic Impact of Indian Gaming on Kumeyaay Nations: A Case Study of Barona, Viejas, and Sycuan, 1982 - 2016" (2017). Theses. 14.                                  California Nations Indian Gaming Association (CNIGA) California Tribal Government Gaming Impact Study.

Description: SANDAG and the Southern California Tribal Chairmen's Association sign a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to begin representation on the SANDAG Board of Directors and on Policy Advisory Committees.
Source: Banegas, Ethan L., "The Socioeconomic Impact of Indian Gaming on Kumeyaay Nations: A Case Study of Barona, Viejas, and Sycuan, 1982 - 2016" (2017). Theses. 14.

Description: The Tribal Transit Feasibility Study is conducted after Caltrans gives San Diego a technical grant. The study analyzes connections between transit district and travel reservations. The study leads to improvements to I-15 and to SR 76, as well as bus route improvements through a Reservation Transportation Authority grant.
The Intertribal Long-Term Recovery Foundation is formed after the wildfires of 2007. The foundation addresses the long-term recovery needs for Native Americans as they relate to natural disasters.
The Imperial Valley Association of Governments completes the "Imperial Valley-Mexicali Economic Delay Study." It quantifies impacts of delays experienced at the POEs in Imperial County.
The San Diego Regional Beach Sand Replenishment Project Feasibility Study is conducted.
The Coastal Regional Sediment Management Program is developed.
The campus successfully concludes The Campaign for UC San Diego, a seven-year initiative that raises more than $1.01 billion in private support from more than 100,000 individuals and organizations.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: Sharp Memorial Hospital and San Diego Cardiac Center participate in the first-ever human gene transfer therapy clinical trial in patients with heart failure.
Scripps Mercy Hospital acquires da Vinci, an advanced robotic surgery system that can make many surgeries less invasive.
The first stretch of I-15 Express Lanes opens.
The San Diego Military Advisory Council (SDMAC) begins conducting its Military Economic Impact Study (MEIS).
The Tribal Transportation Feasibility Study is conducted to understand the connections between the region's tribal reservations and the transit system.
The Global Economic Recesson begins, significantly reducing the number of crossborder trips.

In an effort to address organized crime, U.S. and Mexican federal governments sign The Mérida Initiative. This institutes a higher level of binational cooperation and ushers in a "21st-century border" (included is funding for border security/communications technology improvements). Later phases add Mexico's southern border as a focus for security funding, which impacts the volume of South American immigration.
SANDAG is issued the U.S. Presidential Permit for the Otay Mesa East-Mesa de Otay II POE, and also receives Toll Authority through state legislation (California Senate Bill 1486).
In East County, the Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP) is initiated.

Roger Tsien, PhD, professor of pharmacology, chemistry, and biochemistry at UC San Diego School of Medicine, shares the Nobel Prize in chemistry for his work with glowing proteins, now being used as a surgical aid.
SuperLoop service begins in University City.
The Reservation Transportation Authority is awarded a Tribal Transit Grant to supplement North County Transit District route 388/389.

The Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative (WHTI) requires that all travelers entering the country, foreigners and U.S. citizens alike, present a passport or other accepted document to prove their nationality and identity.
The "Regional Alternative Fuels, Vehicles, and Infrastructure Report" is published by SANDAG.
The Regional Energy Strategy is developed by SANDAG.
SANDAG and partner agencies acquire nine properties totaling nearly 1,000 acres for habitat conservation through the TransNet Environmental Mitigation Program.
SANDAG announces the 2050 Regional Bike Plan.
The Compass Card program is offered to all transit riders, and monthly paper passes are discontinued.
The San Diego Regional Tribal Summit is hosted by the Rincon Band of Luiseño Indians. The emphasis is on tribal employment, and the involvement of tribal nations in tribal transportation projects.
The Office of the Tribal Advisor is created through Exec Order B-10-11, which emphasizes the importance of tribal-state relations.
SANDAG completes the "San Diego and Imperial County Freight Gateway Study," which becomes a key resource for planning around the dynamics of freight movements throughout the border region.
State Route 905 is converted to a full freeway, and a portion is opened to the public.
A Climate Action Strategy is developed by SANDAG.
Energy Roadmap Program launched
Series 12: 2050 Regional Growth Forecast - Historical Projection is adopted.
There are 3,095,313 people in the San Diego region.
State Route 52 opens in March, offering travelers an east-west route from Santee to La Jolla.
The Navy Broadway Complex Redevelopment Project begins.
The 2050 Regional Transportation Plan has a tribal component in the Project Evaluation and Performance Measures criteria.

A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) is signed between key Otay Mesa East Port of Entry project partners (U.S. General Services Administration, U.S. CBP, U.S. Federal Highways Administration, Caltrans, and SANDAG).
A Sustainable Communities Strategy (SCS) for the region is developed. It is the first in the state.

A countywide Conservation and Open Space Element is developed to provide direction for future growth and development in the County of San Diego with respect to the conservation, management, and use of natural and cultural resources; the protection and preservation of open space; and the provision of park and recreation resources.
The last four miles of Express Lanes on I-15 open to travelers.
Daimler launches the first all electric free-float carshare program in San Diego.
State Route 905 is opened to traffic, providing access to the Otay Mesa Port of Entry.
Dole extends its lease at Port of San Diego.

The Moving Ahead for Progress in the 21st-Century Act removes the provision that had allowed Native American tribes to include all preservation transportation facilities. This strips tribal resources to plan for mobility and transportation. (See "2005-2009" for the original laws that were changed.)
The "Helping Expedite and Advance Responsible Tribal Homeownership Act" becomes law. It helps promote home ownership on tribal lands.
Source: Update on Impacts of Tribal Economic Development Projects in San Diego County, April 2003.

Description: California Assembly Bill 307 goes into effect. The state legislation creates state and local mechanisms for federally-recognized tribes to be considered public agencies and enter into joint power agreements (JPAs) with other public agencies.
Viejas enters into a JPA with the Heartland Fire Authority.
Construction of all roadway segments of State Route 905 are completed, connecting the border areas of San Ysidro and Otay Mesa to the I-5 and I-805 corridors.
The California Transportation Commission (CTC) approves the implementation of State Route 11.
The Buena Vista Lagoon Enhancement Project is launched.
The Regional Beach Sand Project is launched.
"The Headquarters at Seaport District" shopping center opens in former San Diego Police headquarters.
Forbes ranks San Diego among the nation’s top ten cities with the greenest cars.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The western portion of the Las Americas Premium Outlets opens in San Ysidro.
The Purchase of Agricultural Conservation Easement (PACE) Program is initiated by the County of San Diego.
Series 13: 2050 Regional Growth Forecast is adopted.
Rapid bus service begins along the I-15 corridor and in the Mid-City area. Routes include Rapid 215, Rapid 235, and Rapid 237. Construction begins on Downtown San Diego Rapid stations.
An expansion of the San Ysidro Freight Rail Yard begins. The important construction project is designed to help expedite loading between freight cars and trucks.
The service area covered by SDG&E reaches 10,000 electric vehicles on the road as California hits the 100,000 mark.

SPAWAR, the U.S. Navy's Space and Naval Warfare Systems Center, employs nearly 10,000 people, and close to 5,000 of them work in San Diego developing the hardware and software that keeps naval forces connected. SPAWAR work injects more than $1.7 billion into the San Diego economy.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: The San Diego Regional Tribal Summit is hosted by the Barona Band of Mission Indians.
The eastern portion of the Las Americas Premium Outlets opens in San Ysidro.

A Memorandum of Understanding is signed between the State of California and the Mexican federal government, forming a binational oversight committee to expedite the Otay Mesa East-Mesa de Otay II Port of Entry project.
President Barack Obama announces an executive action on immigration reform, which grants temporary work permits and indefinite deportation exemptions to four million undocumented immigrants.
A Sustainable Communities Strategy (SCS) for the region is developed.

The J. Craig Venter Institute—a $37 million research facility—is launched by alumnus J. Craig Venter. Researchers focus on everything from continued sequencing and analysis of the human genome, to new research in synthetic biology and cataloging and sequencing of the vast unseen life in the world’s oceans, rivers, and soils.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: The California Department of Public Health designates the five UC medical centers as the state's primary Ebola treatment centers.
The Holiday Bowl begins hosting "Power 5 Conference" teams - the elite of college football in the United States.

Renovations of Trolley Blue Line stations are completed from Barrio Logan to San Ysidro. As part of the Trolley Renewal Project, 65 new low-floor vehicles are added to the Orange and Blue Trolley Lines.
Construction is completed on a .6-mile extension of the Bayshore Bikeway, along Harbor Drive between 32nd Street and Vesta Street.

The San Diego County Water Authority helps develop the nation's largest seawater desalination plant, named the Claude "Bud" Lewis Carlsbad Desalination Plant. Commercial water production at the plant begins in December 2015. Today it produces approximately 50 million gallons of high-quality drinking water each day, further protecting the San Diego region from water supply shortages.
Federal legislation requires that federally recognized tribal governments be consulted in the development of Regional Transportation Plans (RTP) and programs.
Fixing America's Surface Transportation (FAST) Act becomes law. It reinforces a federal emphasis on tribal government participation in transportation matters.

San Diego Forward: The Regional Plan (2015 Regional Plan) and its Sustainable Communities Strategy are approved. The Plan focuses transportation improvements in urban areas, but most tribal members live in rural areas. SANDAG plans on working with different stakeholders including tribal nations.

The Cross Border Xpress (CBX) facility opens to the public in December 2015. It marks a milestone in binational collaboration, and provides a direct connection between the U.S. (via the Otay Mesa area) and the Tijuana International Airport in Mexico.
Construction begins on the Mid-Coast Trolley Extension project - the largest single transportation project in the region's history.
Segment 1 of the SR 11/Otay Mesa East Port of Entry Project, a brand new freeway in Otay Mesa near the U.S.-Mexico border, opens.

The I-805 North Project is completed. It offers travelers two carpool lanes between State Route 52 and Mira Mesa Boulevard. The project also includes a direct access ramp (DAR) at Carroll Canyon Road, which enables carpools, buses, and other eligible vehicles to go straight into High-Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes.

The Port of San Diego establishes a Blue Economy Incubator Program to help create, develop, and scale new business ventures on San Diego Bay. The focus is on aquaculture, or the cultivation of aquatic plants and rearing of aquatic animals for food, and on Blue Tech, particularly the research and development of technology for sustainable ocean use.

Construction of the San Ysidro Freight Rail Yard Improvement Project is completed. The project extended the lead track, which makes it possible to construct larger trains within the yard without blocking the main line and without loss of time. The rail yard enhancements include storm drain upgrades and other improvements to address current drainage issues. A related improvement project, the South Line Rail Freight Capacity Project, enables expanded freight operations to meet existing and future growth of freight rail in the region without interfering with San Diego Trolley service.

UC San Diego Health surgeons perform the region's first heart-liver transplant. The academic medical center is the only local hospital to perform heart-lung, living-donor liver, and multi-organ chest-abdominal transplants.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: An estimated $23 billion in direct defense spending is sent to San Diego County during fiscal year 2016, an amount equal to more than $7,000 for each of the county's residents.
Story: THE U.S. NAVY DROPS ANCHOR IN SAN DIEGO

Description: California Assembly Bill 52 establishes a "Tribal Cultural Resources" category, which requires the consideration of tribal cultural values, scientific values, and archaeological values as part of CEQA.
Source: San Diego Association of Governments/Southern California Tribal Chairmen’s Association. Proceedings for the 2006 San Diego Regional Tribal Summit.

Description: Sustainable Groundwater Management Plans and strategies are implemented. Many tribes participate, as their members live within watersheds throughout the region.
Source:
State of California Department of Transportation/San Diego Association of Governments. Polling Results
from Tribal Transportation Technical Workshop. February 8, 2006.

Description: SANDAG and Caltrans open the first segment of State Route 11 to traffic, which provides access to the future Otay Mesa East-Mesa de Otay II POE. Key freeway connectors are also opened to traffic, linking SR 11 to the SR 905 and SR 125.
A Waste Management Plan for the Alexan - Fashion Valley Project is developed.

As of December 2016, the TransNet Environmental Mitigation Grant Program has helped SANDAG acquire more than 8,600 acres of sensitive habitat in partnership with other organizations and conservation groups.
Major League Baseball sends "All Star Week" to Petco Park.
$28.1 million in improvements to the Oceanside Transit Center are completed. These make the station more efficient by adding a third track and an additional platform.

The Port of San Diego's two marine cargo terminals, Tenth Avenue and National City, process more than 1.8 million tons of cargo including automobiles, agricultural commodities, lumber, and wind energy components.
Cruise ship terminals enjoy increased activity with 88 cruise calls in 2017, more than 14 percent above 2015.
The SANDAG and Armed Forces MOA is revised, appointing the civilian CEO of Navy Region Southwest to the SANDAG Board of Directors and to the San Diego Regional Military Working Group.

The Tribal Consultation Plan is approved by SCTCA and the SANDAG Board of Directors. Elements include leadership meetings between SANDAG and the SCTCA, policy listening sessions, a Tribal Transportation Working Group, a Tribal Summit, and collaboration in the 2019 Regional Plan.
Caltrans and SANDAG begin a pilot program to test technology that uses Wi-Fi detection equipment to measure border wait times.
The Five-Year Countywide Review of the Water Management Plan is published.
The "Management and Monitoring Strategic Plan for Conserved Lands in Western San Diego County: A Strategic Habitat Conservation Roadmap" is initiated.
Sally Roush is the first woman to be named president of SDSU.
In North County, development of the Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP) begins.
The Quino checkerspot butterfly is added to the South County Multiple Species Conservation Program (MSCP).
SANDAG establishes the Regional Housing Needs Assessment (RHNA) Subcommittee, which provides input and guidance during the development of the RHNA Plan.

SANDAG begins recruitment of an Independent Performance Auditor who will report directly to the agency's Board of Directors and Audit Committee. This auditor will oversee and conduct independent examinations of SANDAG programs, functions, and operations.

SANDAG’s binational partnership with the Mexican government is reinforced with the historic first visit to a Board of Directors meeting by the Honorable Luis Videgaray, the Secretary of Foreign Affairs of Mexico.
Dockless mobility explodes in popularity throughout San Diego.
The Port of San Diego secures a grant of nearly $5 million to install a renewable, solar-powered microgrid at the Tenth Avenue Marine Terminal, one of the Port’s two marine cargo terminals.
The Intraregional Tribal Transportation Strategy is developed as an Early Action from the 2015 Regional Plan.

The San Diego Regional Tribal Summit is hosted by the Pala Band of Mission Indians. This is the first time that the region's Native American tribes discuss "Emergency Preparedness and Management" in detail.
A U.S. Presidential Permit authorizing the construction of the Otay Mesa East border crossing is renewed.

The Secretary of Foreign Affairs of Mexico, Luis Videgaray, makes a historic first visit to SANDAG, underscoring the significance of binational and regional collaboration as well as the importance of the SR 11/ Otay Mesa East-Mesa de Otay II Port of Entry project.

UC San Diego is named the top public university in the nation for social mobility by Washington Monthly magazine. One-third of the students in the incoming 2018 class are the first in their families to attend a four-year college, and 40% come from low-income households.
Story: BUILDING A POST-WAR ECONOMY – EDUCATION AND TECH

Description: Real estate brokers, agents, and managers account for more than 4,000 jobs in San Diego County.
More than 10,000 individuals in the region are employed in the insurance industry.
Occupations related to business and financial operations account for more than 92,000 jobs in San Diego County.
The Koman Family Outpatient Pavilion opens to patient care in March of 2018.
South Bay Rapid Service begins between the Otay Mesa Transit Center (at the Otay Mesa international border crossing), the communities of eastern Chula Vista, and downtown San Diego.
Construction begins on the last segments of State Route 11.

The Port of San Diego Cargo terminals and surface transportation infrastructure (roadways and railways)
processed 2.6 million metric tons of cargo in fiscal year 2019.
The San Diego region ranks #2 in the nation in solar installations.

The San Diego Ocean Planning Partnership releases an interactive, user-friendly Web Mapping Application designed to help users better understand the dynamic ocean space and ocean-related data offshore San Diego County.

San Diego Forward: The 2019-2050 Regional Plan is a planning effort that includes an overall vision for the region's future. SANDAG plans on working with different stakeholders including tribal nations. Some of the goals of the region's tribes, in accordance with the Regional Plan, include involving the tribes, improving tribal transportation and funding efforts to tribal lands, and information sharing/technical assistance.
All right-of-way is secured for the site of the future Otay Mesa East POE, as well as remainder of needed right-of-way for SR 11.
The Governors of California, Baja California, and Baja California Sur announce the reactivation of the Commission of Las Californias.
A Climate Action Plan (CAP) for the City of San Diego is approved.
The NAVWAR Redevelopment Exclusivity Agreement is executed.

The United States, Mexico, and Canada Free Trade Agreement (USMCA) is signed by President Donald Trump after several iterations. The agreement is not yet in effect, as it is pending full congressional ratification in Canada.
There are 3,343,355 people in the San Diego region.
Today, Native American reservations encompass more than 127,000 acres in the San Diego region, or about 4% of the region’s land base.

San Diego County has nine tribal gaming facilities, more than any other county in the country. This has created more than 10,000 jobs in the region, $500 million in payroll, and a $1 billion industry with about $263 million in goods and services purchased annually. However, the success of some gaming tribes does not extend to all Native Americans in the region as many still live below the national income average.

Source: Used 2018 Summit Tribal Policy Paper for most of the info on here. https://www.sandag.org/uploads/projectid/projectid_551_25166.pdf
